This PR is making it possible to run against multiple versions of Kafka with a single flag. The CI infrastructure is, however, using one, specific version. So, we won't know if/when something breaks here. It would be great to automate testing against multiple versions.

This task would be non-trivial. It can be a new module that changes the dependency. Or, it can be another test invocation in the same module that overrides the version for the second invocation. (Other options available too.) All this may or may not involve spinning multiple-versions of Kafka clusters via, say, Kubernates.

Overall, this is a complex infrastructure work -- it is totally fine if this is not something you are personally interested in. We'll get there eventually ;-)

@jbonofre : I am not on slack, I will try that. We can chat sometime next week. I will try to set myself up on Slack.
@dhalperi FYI
@dhalperi FYI

Simplest is extra test invocation in one one of the builds (ci, jenkins, or nightly): 
`mvn test -Dkafka.clients.version=0.10.1.1 -Dtest=Kafka\* -DfailIfNoTests=false`.

e.g. we could add this to `/.travis.yml`. This ensures the code itself works ok.

Rebased, added `toNativeTransform()` method to `TransformEvaluator` and translated all remaining translations to native.

@amitsela PTAL?

How it looks now:

Bounded Pipeline:
```java
sparkContext.parallelize(Arrays.asList(...))
_.mapPartitions(new org.apache.beam.runners.spark.examples.WordCount$ExtractWordsFn())
_.mapPartitions(new org.apache.beam.sdk.transforms.Count$PerElement$1())
_.combineByKey(..., new org.apache.beam.sdk.transforms.Combine$CombineFn$KeyIgnoringCombineFn(), ...)
_.groupByKey()
_.map(new org.apache.beam.sdk.transforms.Combine$CombineFn$KeyIgnoringCombineFn())
_.mapPartitions(new org.apache.beam.runners.spark.SparkNativePipelineVisitorTest$PlusOne())
sparkContext.union(...)
_.mapPartitions(new org.apache.beam.runners.spark.examples.WordCount$FormatAsTextFn())
_.<org.apache.beam.sdk.io.TextIO$Write$Bound>
```

Unbounded Pipeline:
```java
KafkaUtils.createDirectStream(...)
_.map(new org.apache.beam.sdk.transforms.windowing.FixedWindows())
_.mapPartitions(new org.apache.beam.runners.spark.SparkNativePipelineVisitorTest$FormatKVFn())
_.mapPartitions(new org.apache.beam.sdk.transforms.Distinct$2())
_.transform(new Function<JavaRDD<...>, JavaRDD<...>>() { @Override ... call(JavaRDD<...> rdd) { rdd.combineByKey(..., new org.apache.beam.sdk.transforms.Combine$CombineFn$KeyIgnoringCombineFn(), ...); } })
_.mapPartitions(new org.apache.beam.sdk.transforms.Keys$1())
_.mapPartitions(new org.apache.beam.sdk.transforms.WithKeys$2())
_.<org.apache.beam.sdk.io.kafka.AutoValue_KafkaIO_Write>
```

Indeed -- but, that approach won't scale for our project-wide needs, and goes against many of the goals we have set out for our engineering system (e.g., easy for contributors to run the tests, no complicated commands to reproduce what the CI is running, interop with plugins, etc.). So, I'd like to go beyond this.

Removed trailing underscores from step name and added a test.
PTAL @staslev

Ok guys, I understand the logic and in that case Dan's recommendation to remove the annotation makes total sense. One question, this means that the IOs should not be annotated with NeedsRunner in their tests ?
I am seeing that BigQueryIOTest has these annotation, so should I remove those too ?

On extra thing that I forgot, I see some value in tagging tests to indicate that they require a runner because this will trigger the nodeEnforcement validations that @staslev put in place, those won't be executed if I remove the NeedsRunner annotation. Other idea would be to have a different annotation to enforce such cases.
Please tell me what do you prefer and I will do it.

Thanks for fixing this, @JingsongLi! I just merged 👍

I have put some info in writing, which I hope this discussion can find useful.
Please feel free to correct me if I got things wrong.

_What are the `@NeedsRunner` and `@RunnableOnService`annotations needed for_?

* `@NeedsRunner` is a way for tests residing in `beam-sdks-java-core` / `beam-runners-core-java` to request the `DirectRunner` to execute them as part of its build cycle.
* `@RunnableOnService` is a way for tests in `beam-sdks-java-core` to request the other runners (e.g. `Spark`, `Flink` runners) to execute them as part of their build cycle. 

The `DirectRunner` is set to specifically search for `@NeedsRunner` tests in `beam-sdks-java-core` and `beam-runners-core-java` during its `integration-test` phase and run them in addition to its own tests. 
```xml
<dependenciesToScan>
  <dependency>org.apache.beam:beam-sdks-java-core</dependency>
  <dependency>org.apache.beam:beam-runners-core-java</dependency>
</dependenciesToScan>
```
Similarly, `@RunnableOnService` tests are searched for and executed by the other runners during the same phase.

```xml
<dependenciesToScan>
  <dependency>org.apache.beam:beam-sdks-java-core</dependency>
</dependenciesToScan>
```

Further aspects in play are the `TestPipeline` JUnit rule,  the `beamTestPipelineOptions`, and `beamUseDummyRunner` system properties. When the `TestPipeline` is used in the scope of a test, it checks the `beamTestPipelineOptions` to determine the pipeline options, among which is the runner class, so each runner module can set its own test settings using the `beamTestPipelineOptions`. 
If `beamTestPipelineOptions` is not set, the `beamUseDummyRunner` system property is inspected, and if set, a special type of runner is set - the `CrashingRunner`, which throws an `IllegalArgumentException` exception upon an attempt to execute the pipeline. `CrashingRunner` is suitable for tests that test pipeline construction only, and do not actually run the pipeline they construct.

_Do tests outside `beam-sdks-java-core` / `beam-runners-core-java` need to be decorated with `@NeedsRunner`/`@RunnableOnService`_?

`DirectRunner` does NOT search for tests annotated with `@NeedsRunner` outside the `beam-sdks-java-core` and `beam-runners-core-java` modules. So even if they are annotated with `@NeedsRunner` they will NOT be executed as part of the `DirectRunner`s build cycle. 
However, modules that wish to run their tests using the `DirectRunner` can set a test scope dependency on `beam-runners-direct-java` and use it as their pipeline runner.

It may therefore seem futile to annotate tests outside the modules  `beam-sdks-java-core` and `beam-runners-core-java` with `@NeedsRunner`, however, this is not entirely the case.
`TestPipeline` offers mechanisms to avoid common pitfalls when designing pipeline tests,  mechanisms that are activated by detecting a `@NeedsRunner` / `@RunnableOnService` annotation on a test. Thus it may be worthwhile adding a `@NeedsRunner` so that these mechanisms are activated and can do their job.

Alternatively, `@NeedsRunner` can be omitted, and these mechanisms can be activated manually by setting `testPipeline.enableAbandonedNodeEnforcement(true)` as part of the test.
It looks good to me. As I'm just CC on this PR, Dan will do the "formal" approval.

So assuming that you (the others) agree with Stas, what is the next step (for the case of these annotations in the IOs [The case that i care in this PR)?  some options:
1. Create a new category to indicate that the running of the tests should be validated using the TestPipeline validations ?
2. Keep  NeedsRunner in the IOs like it is and have this mixed behavior (not really called, but enforced by TestPipeline too).
3. Get rid of all the Categories in the IOs since they are not really enforced (again asuming what Stas wrote) ?

WDYT?
Just curious: what about the other runners (Apex and Flink) ?

Isn't this quite similar to what the example integration tests do ?
https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/4a29131d3c0f490d01820e92e028ec07eaffe927/examples/java/pom.xml#L173-L173
In that case we shouldn't reinvent the wheel and use the existing profiles, no ?
https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/4a29131d3c0f490d01820e92e028ec07eaffe927/examples/java/pom.xml#L41
Agree, and for me it's not really integration tests ;) It's just unit tests on different runners ;)
Yes, anyway this is a valuable idea, a future step would be to have this rule at the top level of the IOs, no ? So they execute the integration tests with all the runners, does this make sense ?

Oh yes, definitely. My point is just a question of naming ;)
A real integration test (as discussed on the mailing list) is running on an integrated/actual platform.

:+1: JB
Other thing been discussed at this moment and co-related, the 'mis-use' of @Category annotations in IO tests. I thought that if we put these annotations, e.g. RunnableOnService they will execute these tests in all the runners, but it does not seem to be the case.
https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/2077
And I mention this in case we want to filter in the future the tests that are executed in all the runners (for speed reason for example).
I didn't think it was needed, since this is a minor change and I wanted also to see if Kenn agreed. But I will create one if it is needed.
No that's OK. Just wanted to be sure it's not a forget.

LGTM.

I ran a few tests and have not seen an issue. One thing I cannot be sure is, if one of our dependencies depends on one of these and they do not install it by default. Far fetched but possible, we need to monitor post commit tests closely after this is merged.
LGTM pending changes just to `@Ignore` unit tests, which shouldn't materially change this PR.

I'll look into this after timestamp support.
Mostly I'll look for a test plugin in pom, so the impact is limited to this module only.

Great, glad to hear you found it helpful and sorry I missed it back when I made the changes.

Will merge once we get the LGTM (@kennknowles ).

Thanks for your comments.

You are quite right that this is very similar to what the example integration tests do. I spent a bunch of time trying to get it working the same way as the example ITs, but it's quite tricky. The problems are:
1.  the runners have a dependency on the IOs - kafka/pubsub in particular. This means you can't have the IO module depend on the runners (and especially not the parent IO)
2. Simultaneously, you have to have all the proper jars included in the classpath for dataflow & spark to be able to pick them up. 
3. You have to pass parameters to the integration test, but can't use beamTestPiplineOptions since if you run verify, it'll also run the unit tests, and those don't understand the pipelineoptions for the IOs.

Between all those issues, I couldn't immediately get an examples-like version of this to work. I really tried :)

As I mention in the commit message (but I'm realizing now, that isn't easily visible here), this is a temporary measure. The long term plan I'm thinking about is to have an aggregator module that depends on both the runner and the IOs, and run the tests there, but I'd like to get the Jdbc IT running so that jason can start having perfkit running and calling this IT. 

I'll update the comments in the file to reflect this.
I've noticed that the error message contains `sys.version` (which contains new lines). I've modified it to `sys.version_info` for the sake of brevity

re: naming - we have to pick some sort of boundary for what's an IT and what's a unit test. These tests meet the criteria of IT as discussed in the draft testing IO doc - I haven't heard any objections there. If we'd like to discuss that, happy to discuss it on dev@, but I'd like to not block this check-in on that.  https://docs.google.com/document/d/153J9jPQhMCNi_eBzJfhAg-NprQ7vbf1jNVRgdqeEE8I/edit?usp=sharing

I see the discussion of @NeedsRunner - my understanding is that only applies to unit tests, not ITs. (I think I was earlier told to remove it from this test.)

also, cc @dhalperi on this conversation as a whole.

It would be _terrific_ if all build-generated files are under `target/` directory. Alternatively, the clean plugin can be configured to clean others too, but that's obviously less desirable. If messing with this, make sure `.gitignore` and `rat` configuration are in-sync.

For the naming, when I read the doc, I see:
```
* Verify that the IO transform can connect to a real instance of the data store running on a different machine, including passing credentials
* Verify that the IO Transform can read/write a small amount of data to a real instance of the data store
```
In this sense, it's not really integration tests, but more unit tests (as we use the JDBC instance embedded and created by the tests).

Honestly, it's not a big deal at all. It's just that what we named IT here sounds UT to me ;)

Hey JB! 

These tests actually do connect to a real postgres instance. You'll note in the comments at the top of the file that you have to pass in connection parameters to talk to a real postgres instance.
